front.title: Modeling the Digital Map based on RFC8345: Sharing Experience

abstract.t: This document shares experience in modelling digital map based on the IETF RFC8345 topology YANG modules and some of its augmentations. Next to sharing experience, it covers the open issues encountered during the modelling phases.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The is a topology-based YANG model with many YANG augmentations for different technologies and service types. The modelling approach based on provides the out of box standard IETF based API.

At the time of writing those lines, there are 60 YANG Modules augmenting , 59 IETF and 1 BBF. 8 have maturity level 'ratified', 15 have maturity level 'adopted', 21 have maturity level 'latest-approved' and 16 have maturity level 'initial'. The up-to-date information can be found in the YANG Catalog at .
From this long series of IETF RFCs and IETF drafts, we attempted to create a Digital Map PoC, with the following objectives and functionalities:

ul.li: Can the central RFC 8345 YANG Module be a good basis to model a Digital Map?
Understanding how the different topology-related IETF YANG modules fit together/
Modelling of digital map entities, relationships, and rules how to build aggregated entities and relationships. Does the base model support all the requirements?
Modelling multiple underlay/overlay layers from layer 2 to layer 3 to customer service layer. Can the base model be augmented for any new technologies?
Can the base model be augmented for any new layer and technologies?
Practically, we developed our proof of concept (PoC) with a real lab, based on multi-vendor devices, with as the base YANG module. The PoC successfully modelled the following technologies:

section.t: - Layer 2 Network Topology (used )
- Layer 3 Network Topology (used )
- OSPF Routing (to be further aligned with )
- IS-IS Routing (to be further aligned with )
- BGP Routing
- MPLS LDP
- MPLS TE Tunnels
- SRv6 Tunnels
- L3 VPN Services
This draft documents our experience in the modeling aspects of the digital map, based on our PoC implementation, basically documenting our work and the open issues encountered.

During the PoC, we also defined the requirements and verified the PoC approach by demoing it iteratively.

section.title: Digital Map and Digital Twin Relationship
Digital Twin?
section.t: The digital twin concepts and the reference architecture of the network digital twin are proposed in the "Digital Twin Network: Concepts and Reference Architecture" NMRG draft .

This draft defines the core elements of digital twin - Data, Models, Interfaces and Mapping. The digital twin network constructed based on the four core technology elements can analyze, diagnose, emulate, and control the physical network in its whole life cycle with the help of optimization algorithms, management methods, and expert knowledge.

Finally, it states that a digital twin network can be regarded as an indispensable part of the overall network system and provides a general architecture involving the whole life cycle of physical networks in the future, serving the application of innovative network technologies such as network planning, construction, maintenance and optimization, improving the automation and intelligence level of the network. section.title: Digital Map
section.t: Digital Map provides the core multi-layer topology model and data for the digital twin and connects them to the other digital twin models and data.
The Digital Map Modelling defines the core topological entities, their role in the network, core properties and relationships both inside each layer and between the layers.

The Digital Map Model is a basic topological model that is linked to other functional parts of the digital twin and connects them all: configuration, maintenance, assurance (KPIs, status, health, symptoms), traffic engineering, different behaviours and actions, simulation, emulation, mathematical abstractions, AI algorithms, etc.

The Digital Map Data consists of virtual instances of network and service topologies at different layers. The Digital Map provides the access to this data via standard API for both read and write, with query capabilities and links to other YANG modules (SAIN , SAP , Inventory , Assets , ...) and non-YANG mode.

section.title: Digital Map as a Prerequisite for Digital Twin
section.t:
One of the important requirements for the Digitalization and Digital Twin is to correlate all models and data to topological entities at different layers in the layered twin network. The Digital Map would provide a virtual instance of the topological information of the network, based on this Digital Map Model. The Digital Map is the first step towards the Digital Twin.
The Digital Map Model and Data will provide this missing correlation between the topology models and data and all other models and data: KPIs, alarms, incidents, inventory (with UUIDs), configuration, traffic engineering, planning (what if), simulation, emulations, actions, behaviours.
Some of these models and data are in the context of device, some in context of network or subnetwork and some in context of customer services, needed for both inner and outer closed-loops.
Therefore, Digital Map is needed to break down data islands and have a digital twin for simulation and closed loop, which is required to solve autonomous networking.
The following are some use cases that require Digital Map:

ul.li: Generic Inventory Queries
Service-> subservice -> resource
Resource -> subservice -> service
Intent/Service Assurance
Service E2E and Per-Link KPIs on the digital map (delay, jitter, loss)
Capacity Planning
Simulation
Closed Loop

section.title: Digital Map Requirements
section.t:
The following are the core requirements for the Digital Map:
Further discussion: should we remove it from this draft and have a separate draft

ol.li: Basic model with Network, Node, Link, Interface entity types
Layered Digital Map, from physical network (layer 2, layer 3) up to customer service and intent

Open and Programmable Digital Map. This includes "Read" to understand the view of the network. It also "Write", not for the ability to directly change the Digital Map Data (ex: changing the network or service parameters), but for offline simulations, also known as what-if scenarios. Doing what-if analysis requires the ability to take snapshots and to switch easily between them. Because we have to distinguish between a change on the digital map for future simulation and a change that reflects the current reality of the network.

Standard based Digital Map Models and APIs, for multi-vendor support. Digital Map must provide the standard APIs that provide for Read / Write and queries. This API must also provide the capability to retrieve the links to external data / models.
Digital Map Models and APIs must be common over different network domains
Digital Map must provide semantics for layered network topologies and for linking external models/data
Digital Map must provide inter-layer and between layer relationships
Digital Map must be extensible with meta data

Digital Map must be pluggable a) We must connect to other YANG modules for Configuration, Inventory, Intent Assurance (SAIN), etc b) Not everything can be in YANG, we need to connect Digital Map YANG model with other modelling mechanisms, both southbound, northbound and internally

Digital Map must be optimized for graph traversal for paths. This means that only providing link nodes and source and sink relationships to termination-points may not be sufficient, we may need to have the direct relationship between the termination points or nodes

section.t:
The requirements [1-6] are automatically fulfilled with RFC8345 and extensions. The requirements [7-8] are partially fulfiled, there may be need for some additional semantics. The requirements [9-11] will need some extensions to the RFC8345. In some cases for [10], the links are already sone by augmenting 'ietf-network' and 'ietf-network-topology'. For others, we need to add some mechanims to link the models and data.

The following are the scope requirements for the Digital Map:

ol.li: Digital Map should contain only topological information
Digital Map entities should contain only properties used to identify topological entities at different layers, identify their roles and topological relationships between them
Digital Map should contain only topological relationships inside each layer or between the layers (underlay/overlay)
Digital Map should only have links to other functional Digital Twin data and models.
ACLs and Route Policies will be outside of the digital map, they would be linked to digital map
Dynamic paths may either be outside of the digital map, part of traffic engineering data/models
Provide capability for conditional retrieval of parts of digital map
Must support geo-spatial, temporal, and historical data

section.t: The following are the arch requirements for the Digital Map:

ol.li: Scale, performance, integration
Initial discovery and dynamic (change only) synch

section.title: How to augment for generic Digital Map extensions
section.t:
Generic Digital Map extensions are the RFC8345 extensions required for all technologies and layers in the Digital Map. We have the following options: - make backward compatible updates to RFC8345 - augment RFC8345 network, node, link and termination point for any changes needed
module: dm-network-topology augment /nw:networks/nw:network: .... augment /nw:networks/nw:network/nw:node: .... augment /nw:networks/nw:network/nt:link: .... augment /nw:networks/nw:network/nw:node/nt:termination-point: ....
This can be a separate draft

section.title: How to augment for new technologies / layers
section.t:
There are already drafts that support augmentation for specific technologies. These drafts augment network, node, termination point and link, but also add different topological entities inside augmentations. For example, we have examples like this: module: new-module augment /nw:networks/nw:network/nw:network-types: +--rw new-topology! augment /nw:networks/nw:network: .... augment /nw:networks/nw:network/nw:node: .... adding list of tps of other type (e.g. tunnel TPs in te draft) ... adding new supporting relationship supporting-tunnel-termination-point (te draft) augment /nw:networks/nw:network/nt:link: .... adding tunnels (te draft)
augment /nw:networks/nw:network/nw:node/nt:termination-point: .... There is need to agree some guidelines for augmenting IETF network topology, so that additional topological information is not added in the custom way. This may either involve - adding concepts from TE and SAP topological augmentations to the core digital map topology in the similar way they were added in the corresponding drafts or - using the TP to model SAP and 'link' to model tunnel in the core Digital Map
This can be a separate draft. Guidelines with examples?

section.name: Conclusions
section.t: Digital Map Modelling and Data are basis for the Digital Twin. During our PoC we have proven that Digital Map can be modelled using . Nevertheless, we proposed some extensions/augmentations to to support Digital Maps. There must be some constraints in regards to how to augment the core Digital Map model for different Layers and Technologies in order to support the approach in our PoC. All entities must augment IETF node, IETF network, IETF link or IETF Termination Point and augmentation can only include new properties.
